TopicTitle: can I get an astronaut to level 3 within the Kerbin/mun system?

Articles.Content:
Jeb and crew seems to have topped off at 2.75, we haven't been interplanetary yet.

Does an Engineer really need to go to another planet (and back) before he knows how to change a tire?

After doing both moons, you can do a short venture just outside Kerbin's SOI and back (if I'm not mistaken, you can eject prograde from Kerbin's orbit and it will catch up and bring you back, but I'm not sure), and that's enough for level 3.

According to here http://wiki.kerbalspaceprogram.com/wiki/Experience he needs 16xp for level 3

 

Orbit the 3 Celestial Bodies within Kerbins SOI are 8,75 XP

Flyby the 3 Celestial Bodies are 6 XP

Landing on the 2 Moons (Mun and Minmus) give 10,35 XP

Plant Flags on the 2 Moons gives 11,25XP

Flying on Kerbin gives 1 XP

 

So all in all if I did not leave anything out you will be able to gain 37,35 XP without the need of going interplenatary. This will give you level 5. Given that the wikipedia is still up to date.

The info in the wiki is still accurate as far as I know, but you're missing one important thing. Those xp amounts are not cumulative.  You only get the points for the most valuable one.  So orbiting Kerbin and planting flags on both moons will only get you to 13.25.  To reach level 3, you don't need to go to another planet, but you will at least need to leave Kerbin's SOI and get into orbit around the Sun.

No, he would get full points for planting flags on both moons, but he does NOT also get the extra xp for landing on each one, orbiting them, or flying by them.  If you fly-by, orbit, land on, and plant a flag on a body, you only get the points for the flag.

You can get level 3 in a single mission with any Kerbal. Usually I build a 3 person craft with 8kms dv, so i can "prep" a whole team at once. I also call this ship the "Gauntlet Runner" - But that's just me.

Part 1: Orbit Kerbin, do a flyby around the mun, land at minmus.
Part 2: From Minmus, leave Kerbins soi from prograde, just far enough that the crew has new reports/observations from the sun. Burn retrograde and fall back into Kerbin

To recap:
(In any order)

i) Orbit Kerbin - Have all Kerbals get out and do report
ii) Mun flyby (anything in Mun SOI is sufficient) - Have all Kerbals get out and do report
iii) Land on Minmus - Have all Kerbals get out and do report, get samples, plant flags
iv) Leave Kerbins SOI - Have all Kerbals get out and do report

Upon landing back at Kerbin all Kerbals will be level 3. Don't know what everything is worth but I know it's the easiest way to get to level 3.

It would be, if it was the way it worked. But it doesn't. You don't have to do it in the same mission for it to overwrite. If you orbit Mun and then 18 years and 152 mission later plant a flag on Mun, the Mun XP will be equal to the flag XP, not (flag + orbit) XP.

So to maximize XP, just plant flags everywhere. except Kerbin. Orbiting is more XP than planting a flag because it's harder.

The reason we do the "Mun flyby, escape Kerbin SOI, land on Minmus and plant a flag" mission is because if you add up those XPs it is JUST enough to get to level 3. Once you're at level 3, you're halfway to anywhere fully leveled up, essentially.

That would be silly, but it's incorrect.  Your Kerbal gets the experience from the most valuable action they've completed at each SOI.

The order of value is flyby, orbit, flight, land, plant flag.  (flight is only for bodies with an atmo.)

There is no experience value in doing multiple trips.  If you went on a Mun flyby and came home your Kerbal has the flyby experience value.  If you later go and land on the Mun with the same Kerbal, then that Kerbal gets the value for 'land on Mun' instead of the value for 'flyby Mun', not added.  It makes no difference if you land on the Mun in your first mission or the second, you still have the same experience value for Mun.

Once your Kerbal plants a flag in an SOI other than Kerbin, that's it.  There is no more experience they can gain in that SOI.

Happy landings!
